channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: U.N. Panel Faults China on North Korean Refugees
item.description: A human rights report that found evidence of crimes against humanity in North Korea also said China had failed to meet its responsibility to refugees under international law.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The North Korean leader Kim Jong-un.

item.title: 4 Killed, Including a Police Officer, as Thai Police Move in on Protests
item.description: At least 64 people were injured when thousands of riot officers tried to dislodge protesters from the streets around the prime minister’s office.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: American Designs ‘International Style’ Set for CCTV
item.description: The American designer Jim Fenhagen was hired to create a new set for CCTV’s flagship news program, but critics argue that the state outlet’s news content is still in question.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q.&A.: Steven I. Levine on the Tiananmen Initiative Project
item.description: Steven I. Levine, a historian of China who is retired from the University of Montana, explains his effort to encourage candid commemoration of the events that culminated in the 1989 crackdown.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: People's Liberation Army troops guard Chang'an Avenue near Tiananmen Square on June 6, 1989, two days after the square was cleared of student-led demonstrators with a still undetermined loss of life.

item.title: Stuart Hall, Trailblazing British Scholar of Multicultural Influences, Is Dead at 82
item.description: Mr. Hall was a Jamaican-born British academic who focused on societal division and blending.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Stuart Hall helped create the academic field of cultural studies.

item.title: School’s Arab Mascot Draws Fire in California Valley That Prizes Dates
item.description: Coachella Valley High School, in Thermal, Calif., has agreed to redesign its mascot, the Arab, after a petition from the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH WHEATON
item.media:credit: Annie Tritt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Award-winning dates were displayed Sunday at the National Date Festival in Indio, Calif.

item.title: Bombings in Syria Force Wave of Civilians to Flee
item.description: Aerial bombardment by the Syrian government has emptied neighborhoods in the rebel-held city of Aleppo, pushing a new surge of refugees into Turkey, the United Nations says.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A young Syrian ate bread Saturday in an underground warehouse in Kilis, Turkey, that is illegally housing hundreds of refugees.

item.title: Spain, Land of 10 P.M. Dinners, Asks if It’s Time to Reset Clock
item.description: A pro-efficiency movement is pushing Spain, with its long siestas and late nights, to reset its clock to align the country with the rest of Europe’s 9-to-5 schedule and become more productive.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Laura León for The New York Times
item.media:description: Manuel De Soto takes his customary after-lunch nap at home in Seville. For many Spaniards, long siestas mean workdays extend well into the night.

item.title: U.S. Steps Up Criticism of Russian Role in Syrian War
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry sharply criticized Russia’s support of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, saying it was undermining prospects for a negotiated solution.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON DAVID E. SANGER and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Khartoum Journal: Sudanese TV Show, Without the Cutthroat ‘You’re Fired,’ Rewards Entrepreneurs
item.description: “Mashrouy,” Sudan’s version of “The Apprentice,” has kindled the imagination of the nation’s youth, many of whom are unemployed.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:credit: Mohamed Siddig for The New York Times
item.media:description: Samah al-Gadi, center, won “Mashrouy” by using her background in agriculture to create a plan to use a weedlike plant for items like ropes and bags.

item.title: DealBook: 3 Who Worked at Barclays Face Charges in Libor Case
item.description: The Serious Fraud Office of Britain accused the former bank employees of conspiring to manipulate the London interbank offered rate, or Libor, from June 2005 to August 2007.
item.dc:creator: By CHAD BRAY
item.media:description: Barclays and other financial institutions have agreed to pay billions of dollars to settle allegations of rate manipulation with regulators in Britain, the United States and elsewhere.

item.title: Venezuela Cites Unrest in Expelling 3 U.S. Officials
item.description: The consular officials were accused of visiting Venezuelan universities to recruit students to organize antigovernment protests.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN and ANDREW W. LEHREN

item.title: Celebrations, and Unease, in Libya on Anniversary of Uprising
item.description: Libyans took to the streets on the third anniversary of the revolt against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, though many said the country’s leaders had squandered the revolution.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Libyans waved flags and honked horns in Tripoli on Monday. The crowds appeared undaunted even when a small car bomb exploded yards from Martyrs’ Square.

item.title: Nobel Winner’s Frank Advice to China’s Leadership
item.description: To make the transition to a high-income economy, A. Michael Spence calls for bolstering domestic demand and exposing state firms to more market pressure.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN SCHLEFER
item.media:credit: Angel Valentin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A. Michael Spence, a 2001 Nobel Prize winning economist, is an expert on the Chinese economy.

item.title: Op-Docs: ‘VHS vs. Communism’
item.description: In Communist Romania, Chuck Norris and Bruce Lee became popular heroes thanks to a translator who illicitly dubbed thousands of foreign films.
item.dc:creator: By ILINCA CALUGAREANU

item.title: Russia to Release Loan Money for Ukraine, Lifting Leader
item.description: The Russian move does an end run around Europe’s sluggish efforts to support the Ukrainian opposition by coming up with an aid package of its own.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ALISON SMALE

item.title: World Briefing: South Korea: At Least 10 Die as Resort’s Roof Collapses
item.description: The roof of a resort’s auditorium collapsed during an orientation ceremony for university freshmen in southeastern South Korea, officials said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,297 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: France Tries to Tempt In More Foreign Investment
item.description: Hoping for foreign investment, France’s president pledged tax stability to a group of high-ranking executives from the world’s multinationals. But forgetting some of his campaign rhetoric may not be easy.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: At the Élysée Palace, President François Hollande reiterated that he would cut social charges to companies by €30 billion.

item.title: From India, Proof That a Trip to Mars Doesn’t Have to Break the Bank
item.description: India’s recently launched mission to Mars was remarkable for its relatively low cost given the normally sky-high expense of space exploration.
item.dc:creator: By SARITHA RAI

item.title: ArtsBeat: Cornelius Gurlitt, German at Center of Art-Cache Case, Sets Up Website
item.description: The site seeks to present Mr. Gurlitt’s side of the legal dispute over the fate of the hundreds of pictures that were removed from his apartment in 2012 by German prosecutors.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Take a Number: Why Russian Men Don’t Live as Long
item.description: A Russian male has a 1-in-4 chance of dying before he turns 55 years old, compared with a 1-in-11 chance for American men. Blame the vodka and cigarettes.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL NUWER

item.title: Kim Yu-na Seeks Consecutive Figure Skating Golds
item.description: Kim Yu-na of South Korea can become only the third woman to win consecutive Olympic gold medals in figure skating; Yulia Lipnitskaya of Russia can be youngest champion in 16 years.
item.dc:creator: By JERÉ LONGMAN
item.media:description: Kim Yu-na of South Korea trains for her chance at a second Olympic gold in women's figure skating.

item.title: Pakistan Suspends Taliban Peace Talks Over Killings
item.description: The government refused to meet with Taliban representatives after the reported killing of 23 paramilitary soldiers in militant captivity.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Chinese Officials Widen Campaign Against Vices
item.description: The operation appears intended to send a message similar to the so-called anticorruption campaign promoted by President Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
